Award.AwardTitle: Hawaii-Fiji collaboration: workshop on social-ecological resiliency to climate change, preliminary data collection, and methods training
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hawaii-Fiji collaboration: workshop on social-ecological resiliency to climate change, preliminary data collection, and methods training

People who live on small islands are involved in tight feedback loops that make them acutely aware of how anthropogenic and natural influences affect their resources. Pacific Islanders have developed traditional ecological knowledge and resource management systems to deal with high levels of environmental uncertainty and resource scarcity, and may be able to teach us important lessons about adaptive capacity and resilience in coupled human and natural systems. A cross-disciplinary team of researchers from the University of Hawai?i
(USA) and the University of the South Pacific (Fiji) will hold a planning workshop, teach a short training course in social-ecological methods and approaches to studying resilience in coupled human natural systems, collect baseline data, and develop a collaboration that has the capacity to test if and under what conditions traditional ecological knowledge and traditional resource management can enhance adaptation and resilience to climate change in the Pacific Islands.
This project builds capacity in research and education. It provides cross-disciplinary training for undergraduate and graduate students and an international research experience that can lead to longer term collaborations. By targeting Pacific Islanders in recruitment, this initiative will broaden the participation of an under-represented group. In establishing a collaboration among US researchers from different disciplines (social and natural sciences, marine and terrestrial spheres), and between US and Fijian researchers with complimentary expertise, this project develops a network that has the capacity to address complex issues that can contribute to policy for improving strategies for resilience and adaptation to climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unraveling strategies that underlie adaptability to climate change requires exploring complex interactions within and among coupled human and natural systems, and poses one of the most pressing problems today.  It is essential that we understand how coupled human and natural systems function and learn what strengthens their resilience, so that these lessons can be broadly applied. Pacific Islands are essential to this study, not only because they are  vulnerable to the effects of climate change, but also because people who live on small islands are often able to see the limitations of their environment more readily, and more quickly understand how anthropogenic and natural influences affect resource availability.  As a result, they may learn, respond, and adapt more quickly compared to people who live on continents. Pacific Islanders, then, through the traditional ecological knowledge and resource management systems they have developed and continue to adapt, may be able to teach us important lessons about adaptive capacity and resilience in coupled human and natural systems.

The aim of this project was to develop a new collaboration between researchers at the University of Hawaii (UH in Honolulu, Hawaii) and the University of the South Pacific (USP in Suva, Fiji) with the aims of (i) developing a proposal to test if and under what conditions traditional ecological knowledge and traditional resource management enhance adaptation and resilience to climate change in the Pacific Islands; and (ii) providing cutting edge educational opportunities for students.

 In September 2012, we conducted a workshop with UH and USP faculty and students, on identifying research priorities for better understanding the links between local ecological knowledge/customary management, and resilience to climate change in the Pacific Islands. The three day workshop involved an interdisciplinary mix of faculty and graduate students from UH and USP as well as from other institutions in Fiji (Wildlife Conservation Society-Fiji, Fiji Locally Managed Marine Areas network) and from other parts of the Pacific (Vanuatu Meteorological Dept, Kiribati Climate Action Network, and Waikato University, New Zealand).  A total of 27 participants, including 14 students participated, representing nine Pacific Island countries.

 After the workshop, we carried out a three day training for UH and USP graduate students. This involved field visits – including an overnight stay in a Fijian village to visit agroforests and coral reefs - presentations by UH, USP and University of Waikato faculty, as well as student presentations and exchange on research methodologies. Prior to the workshop, we coordinated an online exchange and collaboration between UH and USP through an upper level undergraduate course and a graduate seminar.

 Based on our workshop and a synthesis of the existing literature, we published a multi-authored peer-reviewed publication in an open-access journal. Our paper* reviews what we know about customary resource management/local ecological knowledge and its links to resilience in the Pacific Islands. It integrates social and ecological aspects, including marine and terrestrial spheres and sets out a research agenda.

Based on all of the above, we submitted an interdisciplinary grant proposal to the NSF Coastal SEES program (Jan 2013), “Linking local ecological knowledge, ecosystem services and community resilience in Pacific Islands” that was funded.

The workshop, training and preliminary research provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science. Our project involved five UH students and 7 USP students.
